title: False Identification of Faces in Children and Adults
abstractText:
The task of establishing identity via a facial image is commonplace and is conducted routinely by police officers, passport officers, surveillance experts and those working within the criminal justice system. 

However, it has recently become clear that this method of establishing identity is highly error prone.  There are two types of errors that can be made.  The first is a failure to confirm identity when two faces do indeed belong to the same person.  The second is falsely asserting that two faces are of the same person, when they are not.  An example of this type of error was the tragic shooting of Jean Charles de Menezes in 2005. 

This project will explore both types of error, but the focus will be on false identification.  The main aim of the study is to investigate patterns of responding on a range of face matching tasks, at five different ages (6, 8, 10, 12 and 14 years), and to compare this with adult performance on exactly the same tasks. 

The results of this research will help to establish what drives false identification of faces (in both children and adults) and recommendations regarding how to reduce such errors will be made.
